text: Piggybacking on <@UUXPJ96EQ>'s question here, those who saw Quora working for lead-gen, what messaging/method did you use to promo the asset? I'm new to Quora so this is a very interesting thread. Let me know if you'd like me to ask it as a new question in the channel instead!

text: Not a contract per say but just hold off on giving them the leads unless they prove they completed the actions. The requirements are usually: 1 dedicated email promoting the content to their email list, 1 social post on each platform (LinkedIn, Twitter, Facebook and Instagram if they have it)

text: Hi <@U01340H0VD5>! I've already mentioned above which products/audiences work for lead gen on Quora, and here are a few words on how we were doing there. When I was working at Serpstat (SEO tool), we used Quora to drive sales. The idea was to find questions that feature competitors (e.g. What are the alternatives of Ahrefs?') and tell about the tool and why it's a better alternative to the above-mentioned one. We posted only organic answers (no paid activity) and this was delivering great results.

text:
Adding to the above.. two things:
1 - Give the comms team a space to put announcements. Could be medium, a “press” blog”, or something else…
2 - Post them and bury them like <@UJG9WTEKG> suggested. Sometimes I think people confuse “I need a blog post” with “I need a URL to point people to”

text:
I ran global content for Eventbrite before COVID gutted us. We had two types of content: global and regional.

Regional content was produced to address regionally-specific needs and interests that weren't shared across regions. Global content was applicable to 3/4ths of our regions, meaning it was produced to address needs and interests that spanned multiple regions.

How we determined what was regional vs. global was done during the planning process. If, for instance, there were identical inputs from regional stakeholders and data sources, that was a global piece. But if a regional input was deemed a priority in that region, it was a regional piece.

We produced global content centrally with a modular mindset. For example, my team would work with Instagram to create an ebook and write the core sections that featured their subject matter expertise. Then the regional teams would develop the regionally-specific examples and such before translating the core sections.

That's just one example. The whole operation was more nuanced than that.

We produced global content centrally with a modular mindset. text:
An NGO I worked for had 2 sites (navigable to each other in the main menu)—one for French content, one for English. In newsletters, you can either segment your audience by language, or the clunkier version is to have the English first, followed by the translated version. If your main website will be in English, but you want content to be consumed in either language, maybe you could just have 2 blog options on your site—one for English, one that’s entirely your second language.

Once you commit to a method, your audience will adapt. And/or you can ask them for feedback—if they’re fine with just English or have an easier solution, don’t make extra work for yourself!

text: I wasn't involved in the planning and strategy, but I wrote content for Salesforce Marketing and Commerce Cloud's, and at the time, we used the method of writing/creating content in English, first, then we would send finished assets to our various European, Asian, etc. content teams to translate. I remember the biggest struggle not necessarily being the translation of content (though we did have to re-write things occasionally). It was more how things like stats and data were presented. Even in something as small as an ad, different countries had more rigorous regulations as to how research was attained, how it could be published, etc. We had a person dedicated to knowing those regulations and reviewing our content on the international content teams to for feedback and approval.

I remember the biggest struggle not necessarily being the translation of content (though we did have to re-write things occasionally). It was more how things like stats and data were presented. Even in something as small as an ad, different countries had more rigorous regulations as to how research was attained, how it could be published, etc. We had a person dedicated to knowing those regulations and reviewing our content on the international content teams to for feedback and approval.

text:
Oh! Two other things that I’m reminded of:

1- Posting press/announcement stuff that is outdated within days can be bad for SEO reasons. Theres a school of thought that “index bloat” can act as a drag on your rankings. I’ve been in roles where we deleted the bottom 20% performing content and it lifted the performance of the other 80%.

2 - If they wont budge, spin it so every announcement gets blog treatment. For example, rather than just announcing there is a new feature, write the definitive blog post on how use the feature to do X Y Z. Or if theres a new partnership announced, interview someone senior at the partner about whatever your audience cares about (I.e. productivity tips, business wisdom, etc). Make the “announcement” useful for months to come. (This takes resources away from your other stuff, but would be helpful in the long run)

text:
We’ve got an English site, and four localized sites (French, Spanish, Dutch and Czech). Our app is available in all five languages too. Ideally, we’d translate everything but that’s not always possible, so our prioritization works as follows:
1. App translations
2. Feature Announcements (“look what we’ve built”)
3. Features (“this is what our app can do, and the problem it solves”)
4. Support content (“Here’s how to use the app”)
5. Blog content and our Academy content (content that our audiences are interested in, hopefully :crossed_fingers:)
We have a newsletter that we send out in 5 languages too. And here’s where it gets interesting, we can’t always translate all of the content we include in the English one (which is leading), so we selectively translate. For instance, the Dutch are fine with English content, Spanish speaking folks too, but the French and the Czech really prefer to read content in their own language. So when we know we can’t localize everything, we focus on the markets that _really_ need the translations.

We’ve got a translation manager who works with our translators.

Whether or not we translate content is dictated by the business value it has, either from a commercial point of view and/or from a search point of view. From a search point of view, ideally you’d like to have all of your blog / academy content translated. At what point does it stop being interesting to translate everything? Probably when you see you’re dominating a market, when you see you’ve peaked, when a certain market stops converting as well as it did etc.

text: :point_up_2:This is why I'm partial to moving this type of content to its own URL. Anyone with SEO sense is going to hate these posts, but they serve a variety of legitimate business purposes -- recruiting, investor relations, partner communications, etc. Trying to make a piece work for both search and partners is a _pain_. It's better to have a dedicated place for content that serves a very different purpose that is not search.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

. It's better to have a dedicated place for content that serves a very different purpose that is not search.

text:
When updating your content, what do you do with posts that still get traffic but are completely irrelevant to the rest of your blog?

Context: we have a lot of posts <https://www.wildapricot.com/blogs/newsblog/2009/03/03/low-cost-magazine-publishing-on-demand|like this one> that are just so random and out of date, yet somehow still rank.

I hate coming across them because they're so irrelevant, but I didn't delete them in the rest of my blog purge because they were still getting some traffic... nor did I want to bother to update them since I couldn't really find a way to make it relevant to the rest of our content :stuck_out_tongue:

As it stands, I've just been leaving them up to get some random passive traffic, but I'm wondering if I should try to take even more advantage by updating them and innerlinking them better...

Or, since they're so off base to our current content, whether I should just take the hit and delete them.

Any thoughts?

text: Following! I have a couple of those on the company blog. I need to figure out what to do with them!

elements.text: Following! I have a couple of those on the company blog. I need to figure out what to do with them!

text:
Could you consolidate the posts that might have similar themes? Example: if you have two posts that are meh, could you combine them (one post subsuming under another one), using the one that receives the most traffic? Then 301 redirect to the updated post.

Another line of questions to consider: What is the traffic level like? If its low and irrelevant traffic to what you’re writing now, why bother keeping it? The engagement might not be great, which could impact how Google crawls your pages (tons of irrelevant traffic, high bounce = you’re not delivering what users were looking for anyways!)

If its low traffic and low engagement, I’d say axe it and focus on writing content for the expertise area you are in and call it a day.
